title: 2  Activity 03

text: 7.1 Reflections, the plus symbol allows us to add altercations to the graph, furthering the stylistic and technical capabilities of the plot…

title: 1  Activity 02
text:
library(tidyverse) # Load data elections <- read.csv(“https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv”)

2 Check it out
head(elections)


3 Set up the plotting frame


4 How does this differ than the frame for our histogram of repub_pct_20 alone?
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16))


5 Add a layer of points for each county


6 Take note of the geom!
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) + geom_point()


7 Change the shape of the points


8 What happens if you change the shape to another number?
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) + geom_point(shape = 8)


9 YOU TRY: Modify the code to make the points “orange”


10 NOTE: Try to anticipate if “color” or “fill” will be useful here. Then try both.
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16, color = “orange”)) + geom_point()


11 Add a layer that represents each county by the state it’s in


12 Take note of the geom and the info it needs to run!
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) + geom_text(aes(label = state_abbr))


13 The biggest differences in republican support between ’16 and ’20 was an increase in support amongst the percentage of people that voted republican, it seems that the dots tend to have shifted upwards in ’20. There seems to be a strong, positive relationship between support in ’16 and ’20. Left leaning states seem to be clustered around the bottom of the line, in areas with the lowest amount of Republican support, whereas the areas that saw the biggest increase where in right leaning states.
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth()


14 Removing the individual glyphs
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) + geom_smooth()


15 Part b
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = “lm”)


16 Excersize 5


17 Scatterplot of repub_pct_20 vs median_rent
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = median_rent)) + geom_point() geom_smooth(method = “lm”)


18 Scatterplot of repub_pct_20 vs median_age
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = median_age)) + geom_point() geom_smooth(method = “lm”)


19 Exercise 6

scatter plots aren’t good plots when there is both a quantitative and a categorical variable present. This is because the different types of variables don’t align, and on the axis with the categorical variable, you will be unable to see the range of the variable.

ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) + geom_point()


20 Exercise 7


21 Side-by-side violin plots
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) + geom_violin()


22 Side-by-side boxplots (defined below)
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) + geom_boxplot()


23 Exercise 8
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20)) + geom_density()


24 Exercise 9


25 Name two “bad” things about this plot
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) + geom_density() - The over lapping of the data hides potential trends, and the graph is generally confusing with the labels given.


26 What does scale_fill_manual do?
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) + geom_density() + scale_fill_manual(values = c(“blue”, “purple”, “red”)) - The scale fill manual allows you to control the colors you use in the plot.


27 What does alpha = 0.5 do?


28 Play around with different values of alpha, between 0 and 1
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) + geom_density(alpha = 0.5) + scale_fill_manual(values = c(“blue”, “purple”, “red”)) - Alpha changes the transparency of the colors on the plot.


29 What does facet_wrap do?!
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) + geom_density() + scale_fill_manual(values = c(“blue”, “purple”, “red”)) + facet_wrap(~ historical) - This creates seperate plots for each variable


30 Let’s try a similar grouping strategy with a histogram instead of density plot.


31 Why is this terrible?
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) + geom_histogram(color = “white”) + scale_fill_manual(values = c(“blue”, “purple”, “red”)) - this is terrible becuase it doesn’t show any trends and is very confusing in general.
#Exercise 10

title: 4  Note 02
text:

Date: “9/16” - The next step in the class will be multivariate models, where we add a third variable into our equations.

title: 3  5.1 Review
text:
#Date: "09/16/2024"
#Author: "RILEY COGAN"



library(tidyverse)

# Import data
weather <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/weather_3_locations.csv") |> 
  mutate(date = as.Date(date))  

# Check out the first 6 rows
# What are the units of observation?
head(weather)

        date   location mintemp maxtemp rainfall evaporation sunshine
1 2020-01-01 Wollongong    17.1    23.1        0          NA       NA
2 2020-01-02 Wollongong    17.7    24.2        0          NA       NA
3 2020-01-03 Wollongong    19.7    26.8        0          NA       NA
4 2020-01-04 Wollongong    20.4    35.5        0          NA       NA
5 2020-01-05 Wollongong    19.8    21.4        0          NA       NA
6 2020-01-06 Wollongong    18.3    22.9        0          NA       NA
  windgustdir windgustspeed winddir9am winddir3pm windspeed9am windspeed3pm
1         SSW            39        SSW        SSE           20           15
2         SSW            37          S        ENE           13           15
3          NE            41        NNW        NNE            7           17
4         SSW            78         NE        NNE           15           17
5         SSW            57        SSW          S           31           35
6          NE            35        ESE         NE           17           20
  humidity9am humidity3pm pressure9am pressure3pm cloud9am cloud3pm temp9am
1          69          64      1014.9      1014.0        8        1    19.1
2          72          54      1020.1      1017.7        7        1    19.8
3          72          71      1017.5      1013.0        6       NA    23.4
4          77          69      1008.8      1003.9       NA       NA    24.5
5          70          75      1018.9      1019.9       NA        7    20.7
6          71          71      1021.2      1018.2       NA       NA    20.9
  temp3pm raintoday risk_mm raintomorrow
1    22.9        No     0.0           No
2    23.6        No     0.0           No
3    25.7        No     0.0           No
4    26.7        No     0.0           No
5    20.0        No     0.0           No
6    22.6        No     0.8           No

# The unit of observation is Australian days.

# How many data points do we have? 
dim(weather)

[1] 2367   24

# We have a total of 2367 data points

# What type of variables do we have?
# We have both categorical and quantitative variables. 

# Example 1

ggplot(weather, aes(x = date, y = temp3pm)) + 
geom_point()

Warning: Removed 19 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).








# Example 2

# Plot 1 (no facets & starting from a density plot of temp3pm)
ggplot(weather, aes(x = temp3pm)) + 
  geom_density()

Warning: Removed 19 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_density()`).








# Plot 2 (no facets or densities)
ggplot(weather, aes(x = temp3pm)) + 
  geom_boxplot()

Warning: Removed 19 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_boxplot()`).








# Plot 3 (facets)
ggplot(weather, aes(x = temp3pm)) + 
  geom_density() + 
  facet_wrap(~location)

Warning: Removed 19 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_density()`).










#


# Exercise 5.3

# Import and check out data
education <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/sat.csv")
head(education)

       State expend ratio salary frac verbal math  sat  fracCat

5 California  4.992  24.0 41.078   45    417  485  902  (15,45]
6   Colorado  5.443  18.4 34.571   29    462  518  980  (15,45]

#Exercise 1
#- Part A

ggplot(education, aes(y = sat)) + 
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
